elements.content: The hetero valence copper-based metal−organic framework structure {[CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)·H2O][CuI(1,3-NCS)2]} n (2) was constructed from the aqua-bridged [Cu2] complex [Cu2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]ClO4·1.5H2O (1·1.5H2O) of the N4O3 coordinating heptadentate imidazolidinyl phenolate Schiff base ligand, H3L (2-(2′-hydroxyphenyl)-1,3-bis[4-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-3-azabut-3-enyl]-1,3-imidazolidine). Thiocyanate coordination induced aqua bridge cleavage and reductive extrusion lead to the formation of Cu(NCS)2 − anions as a molecular building block and generation of one-dimensional (1D) anionic chains as an extended coordination framework host in 2 and quantitatively replace all the ClO4 − ions from 1·1.5H2O via anion metathesis. Once formed these chains trap the original [Cu2] cationic units in a layer. The copper atoms of 2 are in a distorted square-pyramidal environments around copper ions and are held together by phenolate, imidazolidinyl, and aqua bridges at 3.29 Å intrametallic CuII···CuII separation. Within the anionic part the presence of two “symmetric” end-to-end thiocyanate bridges with CuI−SCN and CuI−NCS distances of 2.61 Å (av.) and 1.924 Å (av.), respectively, results in a CuI···CuI separation of 5.51 Å (av.) within the linear chain. The cationic part of 2 exhibits a weak ferromagnetic exchange interaction (J/k B = +13.0(5) K or J = +9.0 cm−1 and g = 2.25(1)) between the two CuII ions (S = 1/2) and implies that the complex possesses an S T = 1 spin ground state in good agreement with the M vs H data below 8 K.

Thiocyanate coordination induced aqua bridge cleavage and reductive extrusion lead to the formation of Cu(NCS)2 - anions as a molecular building block and generation of one-dimensional (1D) anionic chains as an extended coordination framework host in 2 and quantitatively replace all the ClO4 - ions from 1⋅1.5H2O via anion metathesis. Once formed these chains trap the original [Cu2] cationic units in a layer. The copper atoms of 2 are in a distorted square-pyramidal environments around copper ions and are held together by phenolate, imidazolidinyl, and aqua bridges at 3.29 Å intrametallic CuII⋅⋅⋅CuII separation. Within the anionic part the presence of two "symmetric" end-to-end thiocyanate bridges with CuI-SCN and CuI-NCS distances of 2.61 Å (av.) and 1.924 Å (av.), respectively, results in a CuI⋅⋅⋅CuI separation of 5.51 Å (av.) within the linear chain. The cationic part of 2 exhibits a weak ferromagnetic exchange interaction (J/k B = +13.0(5) K or J = +9.0 cm-1 and g = 2.25(1)) between the two CuII ions (S = 1/2) and implies that the complex possesses an S T = 1 spin ground state in good agreement with the M vs H data below 8 K.

elements.content: Isothiocyanate coordination driven cupric ion dechelation and extrusion reactions followed by formation of unusual CuINCS based anionic chains as a new diamagnetic coordination framework host have been explored with an aqua and imidazolidinyl phenolate bridged [Cu2] perchlorate complex and entrapment of the cationic part.

elements.content: Water bridged dinuclear cationic complexes of 3d metal ions are important in model studies of metallohydrolases and metallocatecholase that contain and require a bimetallic active site for substrate binding and catalysis. Both bridging and coordinated water molecules play a substantial role in understanding the actual mechanism of action during bridge cleavage and ligand substitution reactions. In model complexes, these loosely bound water molecules either lose a proton to provide hydroxo bridges or are replaced by other monodentate ligands having the potential to bridge the metal ions. At the time of replacement of the water molecules by anions, cluster-like metal−organic assemblies can be obtained, and several recent reports in the literature have shown successful employment of anions as a template in the formation of organic and metal−organic assemblies. In these syntheses, the anionic species plays a templating role by using its directional coordination property and determines the metal ion connectivity pattern and geometry of the final structure. The pseudohalide NCS− with three different linearly disposed atoms is known to coordinate to metal ions in both terminal and bridging modes and can function as a versatile structural bridge of paramagnetic metal ions in a variety of coordination modes. As a bridging ligand the thiocyanate anion can link a pair of metal centers in either an end-on (μ-1,1-NCS, μ-1,1-SCN) or an end-to-end (μ-1,3-NCS) configuration. To date, five distinct bridging modes A to E (Scheme ) have been identified in bi- and polynuclear systems that can be summarized as cis μ-1,3-NCS (A), μ-1,1-NCS (B), μ-1,1-SCN (C), μ3 -1,1,3-SCN (D), μ4 -1,1,1,3-SCN (E).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Water bridged dinuclear cationic complexes of 3d metal ions are important in model studies of metallohydrolases and metallocatecholase that contain and require a bimetallic active site for substrate binding and catalysis. Both bridging and coordinated water molecules play a substantial role in understanding the actual mechanism of action during bridge cleavage and ligand substitution reactions. In model complexes, these loosely bound water molecules either lose a proton to provide hydroxo bridges or are replaced by other monodentate ligands having the potential to bridge the metal ions. At the time of replacement of the water molecules by anions, cluster-like metal-organic assemblies can be obtained, and several recent reports in the literature have shown successful employment of anions as a template in the formation of organic and metal-organic assemblies. In these syntheses, the anionic species plays a templating role by using its directional coordination property and determines the metal ion connectivity pattern and geometry of the final structure. The pseudohalide NCS- with three different linearly disposed atoms is known to coordinate to metal ions in both terminal and bridging modes and can function as a versatile structural bridge of paramagnetic metal ions in a variety of coordination modes. As a bridging ligand the thiocyanate anion can link a pair of metal centers in either an end-on (μ-1,1-NCS, μ-1,1-SCN) or an end-to-end (μ-1,3-NCS) configuration. To date, five distinct bridging modes A to E (Scheme ) have been identified in bi- and polynuclear systems that can be summarized as cis μ-1,3-NCS (A), μ-1,1-NCS (B), μ-1,1-SCN (C), μ3 -1,1,3-SCN (D), μ4 -1,1,1,3-SCN (E).

The various coordination modes described to date for the thiocyanate anion when it acts as a bridge in polynuclear one-dimensional (1D) chains are summarized in Scheme . In μ-1,3-NCS and μ4 -1,1,1,3-SCN bridging modes thiocyanate anions can bridge copper ions to form five different types (F−J) of 1D coordination chains.

The trinuclear assembly of mixed-valence copper(II/I) centers are known to be an essential functional unit in a number of blue multicopper oxidases. It is also known that partial reduction of multimetal assembly of copper ions by Cl− and NCS− anions, which can function both as a reducing agent and a ligand, can afford mixed-valence copper(II/I) complexes.

It is also known that partial reduction of multimetal assembly of copper ions by Cl- and NCS- anions, which can function both as a reducing agent and a ligand, can afford mixed-valence copper(II/I) complexes.

elements.content: We and others have been attracted in the coordinating behavior of the dinucleating imidazolidinyl tris-phenolate ligand H3L (Chart , 2-(2′-hydroxyphenyl)-1,3-bis[4-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-3-azabut-3-enyl]-1,3-imidazolidine) and its close derivative H3L′ (2-(2′-hydroxyphenyl)-1,3-bis[4-(2-hydroxyphenyl)-4-methyl-3-azabut-3-enyl]-2-methyl-1,3-imidazolidine) for various reasons, including their importance in bioinorganic modeling, magnetic properties, or catalytic behavior. Herein we report the synthesis and characterization of a CuINCS based anionic 1D framework host trapped aqua-bridged [Cu2] complex 2 of H3L by replacing ClO4 − ions in 1·1.5H2O, which was obtained following a high-yield synthetic procedure at room temperature recently reported by us. In 2, the bridging aqua molecules originally present with the N2O3 coordinated CuII ions in 1·1.5H2O are not showing ligand substitution reaction with NCS− groups as expected. The structural robustness of the CuINCS chain in one dimension shows excellent inclusion ability for the aqua-bridged [Cu2] complex. The host framework is constructed through self-assembly of active intermediate CuI(NCS)2 − obtained from SCN− induced extrusion of copper ions. The formation of a 1D railroad track-like alignment of CuINCS chains is of fundamental importance for self-replication of the CuI(NCS)2 − units. The self-assembly of CuI(NCS)2 − building units leads to several polymeric structures depending on the nature, size, structure, and geometry of the cationic units present nearby as templates. Here the aqua bridged dimer [Cu2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]+ has been utilized as a novel nearby macrocationic template to produce the 1D chains {[CuI(1,3-NCS)2]−} n .

The formation of a 1D railroad track-like alignment of CuINCS chains is of fundamental importance for self-replication of the CuI(NCS)2 - units. The ligand H3L was prepared according to a modified literature procedure. The amount of copper was analyzed by a standard iodometric titration method. elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials, Methods, and Instrumentations

All the starting chemicals and solvents were analytically pure and used without further purification. Copper(II) carbonate, triethylenetetramine, ammonium thiocyanate, and salicylaldehyde were obtained from SD, Fine Chem, India. The ligand H3L was prepared according to a modified literature procedure. The amount of copper was analyzed by a standard iodometric titration method. The compound was decomposed by heating with concentrated nitric acid to near dryness. The residue was dissolved in water to make up the volume to 250 mL. To a 50 mL of this solution 1 g of iodine was added, and the liberated iodine was titrated with a standard 0.1 M sodium thiosulphate solution.

elements.content: 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the ligand were obtained on a Bruker AC 200 NMR spectrometer using TMS as the internal standard. Infrared spectra were recorded as KBr pellets on a Nicolet Nexus-870 FT-IR spectrometer. The solution electrical conductivity and UV−vis spectra were obtained using a Unitech type U131C digital conductivity meter with a solute concentration of about 10−3 M and a Shimadzu UV 3100 UV−vis-NIR spectrophotometer, respectively. Thermogravimetric (TG) analyses were performed with a heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1 under N2 atmosphere on a NETZSCH STA 409 PC TG-DSC instrument. The room temperature magnetic susceptibilities in the solid state were measured using a home-built Gouy balance fitted with a polytronic d.c. power supply. Powder X-ray diffraction analyses of the complexes were performed using MINIFLEX, AD090911 RIGAKU instrument. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were obtained with the use of a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer MPMS-XL. This magnetometer works between 1.8 and 400 K for dc applied fields ranging from −7 to 7 T. Measurements were performed on a microcrystalline sample of 13.56 mg for 2. As a preliminary test, the magnetization of the sample was measured at 100 K as function of the applied dc field in order to detect the presence of any ferromagnetic impurities. As expected for paramagnetic or diamagnetic systems, a perfectly linear behavior that extrapolates to M = 0 at 0 Oe is observed confirming the absence of ferromagnetic impurities in the sample. AC susceptibility measurements were carried out with an oscillating ac field of 3 Oe at 125 Hz, but it is worth noting that no out-of-phase ac signal has been detected for the sample. The magnetic data are corrected for the sample holder and the diamagnetic contribution using Pascal’s constants. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer model 2400 elemental analyzer.

elements.content:
Caution! Perchlorate and azide salts are potentially explosive, only a small amount should be prepared, and handled with proper care.

X-ray Crystallography

Bluish green block-like single crystals of 2 suitable for single crystal X-ray diffraction were grown from a saturated DCM-MeCN (1:1) solution of the powder compound. The X-ray diffraction intensity data were collected at 293 K on Bruker AXS SMART APEX CCD diffractometer using a crystal of dimensions 0.40 × 0.32 × 0.28 mm3 that uses graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω-scan method. Precise unit cell dimensions were determined by least-squares refinement of 25 strong reflections having 2θ values in the range of 1.87−31.81°. Data were collected at 293 K. A total of 8584 reflections were recorded with Miller indices h min = −12, h max = 12, k min = −16, k max = 15, l min = −22, l max = 23. In the final cycles of full-matrix least-squares on F 2 all non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic thermal parameters and refinement converged at R = 0.0334. The residual electron density is in the range +0.86 to −0.90 e Å−3. The structure was solved using SHELX-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods using SHELX-97. Analytical expressions of neutral-atom scattering factors were employed, and anomalous dispersion corrections were incorporated. CCDC-703889 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 2. These data can be obtained free of charge www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html [or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.; fax: +44−1223/336−033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk].

elements.content: To the ligand solution (0.50 g, 1.09 mmol) in 15 mL of dichloromethane, methanolic solution of triethylamine (0.55 mL, 4 mmol) was added dropwise to have a solution of pH 7−8. Then methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ·6H2O (0.80 g, 2.18 mmol) was added slowly with stirring at room temperature for 10 min. The reaction mixture was then stirred for 2 h and the solvent was removed in air. The deep green precipitate obtained was filtered through a glass frit and washed with water followed by methanol and hexane and finally dried in a vacuum over P4O10. Yield: 0.60 g (75%). Anal. Calc. for C27H32N4O9.5Cu2Cl: C, 44.60; H, 4.44; N, 7.70; Cu, 17.47%. Found: C, 44.32; H, 4.37; N, 7.47; Cu, 17.38%. FT-IR spectrum (cm−1, KBr disk): ν = 3388(b), 2936(m), 1627(s), 1595(s), 1537(s), 1447(s), 1312(s), 1094(s), 914(s), 722(s). Molar conductance, ΛM (MeCN solution) 130 Ω−1 cm2 mol−1. UV−vis spectra [λmax, nm (ε, L mol−1 cm−1), DMF solution] 640 (290), 380 (10365), 273 (22040). μeff (tot) = 2.43 μB ; μeff/Cu = 1.71 μB at 298 K.

elements.content: To the dichloromethane solution (15 mL) of the ligand (0.50 g, 1.09 mmol), a methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.80 g, 2.18 mmol) was added followed by methanolic solution of NaN3 (0.07 g, 1.09 mmol) dropwise with stirring at ambient temperature in air. After 15 min, 0.45 mL (3.27 mmol) of a diluted methanolic solution of Et3N was added and the reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h more. The complex was precipitated as a green solid that was isolated, washed with water, and dried under a vacuum over P4O10. Yield: 1.20 g (80%). Anal. Calc. for C54H56N14O11ClCu4Na: C, 46.66; H, 4.06; N, 14.10; Cu, 18.28%. Found: C, 46.64; H, 4.15; N, 13.98; Cu, 18.50%. FT-IR spectrum (cm−1, KBr disk): ν = 3425(b), 2926(m), 2076(s), 1633(s), 1595(s), 1537(s), 1447(s), 1312(s), 1274(s), 1081(s), 747(s), 625(s). Molar conductance, ΛM: (DMF solution) 73 Ω−1 cm2 mol−1. UV−vis spectra [λmax, nm (ε, L mol−1 cm−1)]: (DMF solution) 650 (150), 398 (2660), 271 (16062). μeff (total) = 3.63 μB; μeff/Cu = 1.81 μB at 298 K.

elements.content: The ligand H3L used in this work was prepared following a modified literature procedure and was characterized by FT-IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectra. The reaction in 1:1 (v/v) DCM-MeOH of H3L with Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O in the presence of NEt3 at pH ∼7−8 in a 1:2:3 molar ratio yielded a green complex [Cu2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]ClO4·1.5H2O (1·1.5H2O) (eq ) (Scheme ). The reaction was carried out in air and at room temperature. The complex was characterized by analytical, spectroscopic, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques. The molar conductivity value of 1·1.5H2O in MeCN (130 Ω−1 cm2 mol−1 at 28 °C) is consistent with 1:1 electrolyte type in solution. Previously, we reported the formation of a μ4-perchlorate bridged tetranuclear complex [Cu4(μ-L)2(μ4-ClO4)]ClO4·4H2O from the same reaction in MeCN. Crystalline inclusion compound 2 was obtained in acetonitrile−methanol from 1·1.5H2O at ambient temperature in low yield via thiocyanate coordination triggered partial copper ion extrusion reaction followed by anion metathesis of ClO4 − anions by extruded [CuI(SCN)2]− anions, resulting in the self-assembled 1D framework host of [CuI(μ1,3-NCS)2] n − (Scheme ). Reaction of 1·1.5H2O with ammonium thiocyanate in aq MeCN is responsible for an immediate Cu-NCS bond formation, reduction of the metal center (CuII → CuI) and its extrusion from ligand chelation producing [CuI(SCN)2]− counteranions in the reaction medium.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Considerations

The ligand H3L used in this work was prepared following a modified literature procedure and was characterized by FT-IR, 1H and 13C NMR spectra. The reaction in 1:1 (v/v) DCM-MeOH of H3L with Cu(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in the presence of NEt3 at pH ~7-8 in a 1:2:3 molar ratio yielded a green complex [Cu2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]ClO4⋅1.5H2O (1⋅1.5H2O) (eq ) (Scheme ). The reaction was carried out in air and at room temperature. The complex was characterized by analytical, spectroscopic, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques. The molar conductivity value of 1⋅1.5H2O in MeCN (130 Ω-1 cm2 mol-1 at 28 °C) is consistent with 1:1 electrolyte type in solution. Previously, we reported the formation of a μ4-perchlorate bridged tetranuclear complex [Cu4(μ-L)2(μ4-ClO4)]ClO4⋅4H2O from the same reaction in MeCN. Crystalline inclusion compound 2 was obtained in acetonitrile-methanol from 1⋅1.5H2O at ambient temperature in low yield via thiocyanate coordination triggered partial copper ion extrusion reaction followed by anion metathesis of ClO4 - anions by extruded [CuI(SCN)2]- anions, resulting in the self-assembled 1D framework host of [CuI(μ1,3-NCS)2] n  -    (Scheme ). Reaction of 1⋅1.5H2O with ammonium thiocyanate in aq MeCN is responsible for an immediate Cu-NCS bond formation, reduction of the metal center (CuII → CuI) and its extrusion from ligand chelation producing [CuI(SCN)2]- counteranions in the reaction medium.

Synthesis of 2 was achieved by slow oxidation of NCS− anions at room temperature during reduction of copper ions (eq ). In 2 the aqua bridged cationic species, which is trapped within the anionic framework, has two weak apical Cu−Oaq bonds not responsible for any kind of deprotonation to produce HO− or O2− bridged species. elements.content: While exploring the assembly of dinuclear CuII complex within H3L or its derivatives with the μ-1,1-N3 − group as exogenous bridging ligand, earlier we synthesized the tetracopper green complex [NaCu4(μ-L)2(μ-N3)2]ClO4·H2O (3·H2O) (Scheme ) from a reaction of Cu(ClO4)2·6H2O with H3L and NaN3 in a CH2Cl2-MeOH mixture in the presence of NEt3 (eq ). Now we find that the reaction of the in situ generated aqua complex 1·1.5H2O with NaN3 resulted in the replacement of bridged H2O by N3 − yielding the already known multicomponent complex 3·H2O arising from the assembly of two neutral [Cu2L(N3)] fragments through the intermediacy of an intercalated Na+ cation via a bridge substitution route. Thus, in contrast, the reaction of 1·1.5H2O with NH4NCS leads to thiocyanate coordinated copper ion extrusion, its reduction and outer sphere anion metathesis by Cu(NCS)2 − to produce 2. This reaction also overrules the possibility of the incorporation of thiocyanate anion between the [Cu2L] fragments and independent existence of the [Cu2L(NCS)] neutral components (Scheme ).

Now we find that the reaction of the in situ generated aqua complex 1⋅1.5H2O with NaN3 resulted in the replacement of bridged H2O by N3 - yielding the already known multicomponent complex 3⋅H2O arising from the assembly of two neutral [Cu2L(N3)] fragments through the intermediacy of an intercalated Na+ cation via a bridge substitution route. Thus, in contrast, the reaction of 1⋅1.5H2O with NH4NCS leads to thiocyanate coordinated copper ion extrusion, its reduction and outer sphere anion metathesis by Cu(NCS)2 - to produce 2. This reaction also overrules the possibility of the incorporation of thiocyanate anion between the [Cu2L] fragments and independent existence of the [Cu2L(NCS)] neutral components (Scheme ).

elements.content: The FTIR spectra of 1·1.5H2O and the cationic part of 2 () are in agreement with the coordination of the Schiff base ligand to copper(II) ions and exhibit broad medium band at 3388 cm−1 characteristic of νOH of aqua bridges. For uncoordinated ClO4 − ions in 1·1.5H2O, the Cl−O stretching vibrations appear at ∼1094 cm−1, which is absent in 2. The mode of binding of thiocyanate to copper(I) ions within the anionic framework of 2 has been established from the FTIR frequency ranges found for three characteristic vibrational modes, the C−N and C−S stretching modes (νCN and νCS) and the N−C−S bending mode (δNCS). All these appear at 2060, 768, and 470 cm−1, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Spectroscopic Characterizations

The FTIR spectra of 1⋅1.5H2O and the cationic part of 2 () are in agreement with the coordination of the Schiff base ligand to copper(II) ions and exhibit broad medium band at 3388 cm-1 characteristic of νOH of aqua bridges. For uncoordinated ClO4 - ions in 1⋅1.5H2O, the Cl-O stretching vibrations appear at ~1094 cm-1, which is absent in 2. The mode of binding of thiocyanate to copper(I) ions within the anionic framework of 2 has been established from the FTIR frequency ranges found for three characteristic vibrational modes, the C-N and C-S stretching modes (νCN and νCS) and the N-C-S bending mode (δNCS). All these appear at 2060, 768, and 470 cm-1, respectively.

elements.content: The electronic spectrum of 2 in MeCN solution () shows several intense absorption bands in the visible region that are assigned to the allowed d-d and charge transfer transitions. It exhibits a broad band at 621 nm (408 L mol−1 cm−1) due to d-d transition. The higher intensity charge transfer transitions are obtained at 370 and 265 nm, with molar extinction coefficients of 790 and 1990 L mol−1 cm−1, respectively, attributed to PhO− → Cu(II), σ(amino) → Cu(II) LMCT and intraligand charge-transfer transitions.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compound 2 in the temperature range 30−700 °C under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1 (). The first weight loss 4.62% in the range of 30−125 °C corresponds to two water molecules (calcd. 4.5%), and a gradual loss of weight of 39.80% in the next step between 125 and 385 °C corresponds to the loss of three salicylidine moieties (calcd. 39.45%) of the L3−. A third weight loss of 11.67% between 385 and 700 °C may be ascribed to the release of CuS (calcd. 11.97%) with a left over residue of 43.92% for CuNCS (calcd. 45.65%). The other two complexes 1·1.5H2O and 3·H2O show stepwise weight losses in a similar fashion in the temperature ranges of 98−104, 130−235, 233−240, 380−405, and 410−420 °C, respectively ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compound 2 in the temperature range 30-700 °C under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2.5 °C min-1 (). The first weight loss 4.62% in the range of 30-125 °C corresponds to two water molecules (calcd. 4.5%), and a gradual loss of weight of 39.80% in the next step between 125 and 385 °C corresponds to the loss of three salicylidine moieties (calcd. 39.45%) of the L3-. A third weight loss of 11.67% between 385 and 700 °C may be ascribed to the release of CuS (calcd. 11.97%) with a left over residue of 43.92% for CuNCS (calcd. 45.65%). The other two complexes 1⋅1.5H2O and 3⋅H2O show stepwise weight losses in a similar fashion in the temperature ranges of 98-104, 130-235, 233-240, 380-405, and 410-420 °C, respectively ().

The asymmetric part of the unit cell of 2 consists of a [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]+ cation, a [CuI(NCS)2]− counteranion, and one guest water molecule H-bonded symmetrically to the cationic part. The cationic part represents a [Cu2] complex bridged by phenolate oxygen (Oph b), imidazolidinyl nitrogen (Nmd), and water oxygen (Oaq) atoms. Several aquo-bridged [Cu2] complexes are known in the recent structural literature. In the square-pyramidal coordination environment, depending on the axial or equatorial positions, the Cu−O bond distances in Cu-μ(OH2) unit vary within an extended range of 1.99−2.74 Å. Thus, on the basis of the observed Cu−O bond lengths and the number of hydrogen atoms attached, the oxygen atoms bridging the copper(II) ions in the cationic part can be ascribed to a water molecule. Further coordinations from imine nitrogens (Nim) and terminal phenolate oxygens (Oph) complete the distorted N2O3 square pyramidal environments around each copper ion. The shared bisquare pyramidal arrangement is made from two noncoplanar tetradentate coordination pockets of the ligand arranged for the N2O2 square bases as shown in Figure . The dihedral angle between these square bases is 140.44° and the Cu1−Oph b−Cu2 angle is 114.11°, which is bigger than 78.57° for Cu1−Oaq−Cu2 angle.

elements.content: Nonplanar imidazolidinyl coordination induced angular binding of aqua molecule (OW) by two copper ions in edge-shared square-based pyramidal environments.
elements.clean_text: 2  Nonplanar imidazolidinyl coordination induced angular binding of aqua molecule (OW) by two copper ions in edge-shared square-based pyramidal environments.

elements.content: This angular arrangement of the binding sites arises from the nonplanar structure of the imidazodinyl spacer which in turn responsible for bridging of a water molecule in lieu of coordination of two of the same in monodentate fashion. The bridging H2O (Oaq) completes the triply bridging pattern leading to an intramolecular CuII···CuII separation of 3.292 Å within the cationic part of the complex.

The bridging H2O (Oaq) completes the triply bridging pattern leading to an intramolecular CuII⋅⋅⋅CuII separation of 3.292 Å within the cationic part of the complex.

elements.content: The variations in the distances in Cu−Oph b indicate that the monatomic oxygen bridges are not symmetric. The observed Cu−Oaq (2.453 and 2.735 Å) distances clearly show that they are for an asymmetric aqua bridge not common in the literature. The reported dinuclear complex cation [Cu2(OH)(H2O)L1(ClO4)2]+ (L1 = a binucleating macrocylic ligand) also has long Cu−Oaq linkages (2.519(12) Å) and an acute Cu−Oaq−Cu angle of 77.3(4)°. The calculation of the least-squares planes defined by the atoms of the square-planar coordination plane including the central atom shows the copper ions to be displaced from the basal planes toward the axial water molecule by 0.188 (Cu1) and 0.070 Å (Cu2), respectively, within the cationic part of 2. As a result, the Cu centers could be considered as square planar, each with a weak axial bond to the O4 water oxygen. The central bridging phenolate oxygen atom adopts a trigonal−pyramidal geometry (sum of the angles around O3 is 331.21°). Within [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)]+, the symmetry of the coordination sphere around two copper(II) ions measured by the Addison parameter (τ) is best described by distorted square pyramids with τ for Cu1 and Cu2 as 0.34 and 0.15, respectively. Thus, the Cu1 center is more distorted with a shorter Cu−Oaq distance of 2.453 Å for greater bonding interaction with bridging aqua oxygen atom. On the basis of the coordination sphere symmetry, it was proposed that in the square pyramid coordination limit (near τ = 0) the magnetic orbitals are mainly d x 2 −y 2 and weak ferromagnetic interactions should result. The Cu−Nmd distances (av. 2.063 Å) are longer than the Cu−Nim distances (av. 1.928 Å). The terminal Cu−Oph distances (av. 1.891 Å) are in the normal range, while the average bridging Cu−Oph b distance is longer at 1.9615 Å. In a cuboidal arrangement, the [Cu2O2] diamond core nicely stacks over the imidazolidine pentagon at a distance of 2.515 Å ().

elements.content: A tetracopper motif of the cationic part was generated around two H-bonded guest water molecules (Figure ). In a face-to-face orientation, the [Cu2] complex traps one water (O5) molecule within, which shows an intricate hydrogen bonding network with two copper coordinated terminal phenolate oxygen atoms [O5···O1 = 2.798 Å; O5···O2 = 2.737 Å] and bridging aqua oxygen atom of the second molecule [O5···O4# = 2.801 Å].

elements.content: Hydrogen bonds are described on the basis of the O···O distances. All these distances are comparable to the O···O distance in ice (about 2.74 Å). The assignment of the apical bridge as water is supported by the Cu−Oaq distances at 2.453 to 2.735 Å. The long apical bridging bonds reflect weak axial interactions as expected for Jahn−Teller sensitive copper complexes in square-pyramidal geometry. The geometry around bridging water O4 is distorted tetrahedral with a short Cu1−O4−Cu2 bond angle of 78.57°. The unit cell packing pattern of the cationic part of 2 shows (Figure and S7) a nice arrangement of the H-bonded [Cu4] molecules along the a axes within the layers of [CuI(μ1,3-NCS)2] n chains.

elements.content: The new CuINCS based 1D coordination chain is formed from self-assembly of extruded Cu(NCS)2 − anions which quantitatively replaces all the ClO4 − anions of 1·1.5H2O (). The cationic Cu2 complex serves as template during this condensation and gets trapped within the layers of newly formed CuINCS chains in a different orientation and H-bonding pattern. Within this chain the neighboring Cu+ ions, in tetrahedral geometry, are doubly linked by two NCS− ions in an antiparallel fashion to form a 1D chain running along the b axis. The interval distance between these Cu+ ions is 5.510 Å. The stacked cationic layers are separated uniformly by the [CuI(μ1,3-NCS)2] anions condensed as a 1D framework structure in 2. To the best of our knowledge, the X-ray structure of this anionic chain has never been reported before. The Cu3 atom shows a severely distorted tetrahedron in N2S2 coordination environment and shows two Cu−S bond lengths with distances of 2.663(7) and 2.557(7) Å and two Cu−N bond lengths of 1.9186(17) and 1.9300(17) Å with bond angles in the range of 95.25(5)° to 134.29(8)°. The N−Cu−S angles lie in the 95.25(5)° to 114.24(6)° range, whereas N−Cu−N and S−Cu−S angles are 134.29(8)° and 108.83(2)°. The independent NCS− ligands bridge copper(I) ions to form a novel [Cu(μ1,3-SCN)2] n tapes running parallel in b direction (Figure ).

elements.content: The Cu−S distances in our system are longer than those reported in the polymeric compound {[C5H6N][Cu2(NCS)3]} n where it lies in the 2.319(3)−2.493(4) Å range. The thiocyanate ligands function as linear linking motifs to bridge copper(I) centers to make the coordination framework with negative charges. Within this anionic structure, two Cu atoms are bridged by double μ1,3-NCS ligands in cis coordination mode and head-to-tail fashion forming almost planar eight-members Cu(NCS)(SCN)Cu rings.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The magnitude of magnetic interaction within the metal-organic molecular structure {[CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)⋅H2O][CuI(μ-1,3-NCS)2]} n  (2) was evaluated by means of magnetic susceptibility measurements under an applied dc field in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the χT product for complex 2 at 1000 Oe (with χ being the magnetic susceptibility equal to M/H). The red solid line is the best fit of the experimental data using the S = 1/2 dinuclear Heisenberg model described in the text. The inset show the Cu(II) complex with Cu−O−Cu bond angles.
elements.clean_text: 8  Temperature dependence of the χT product for complex 2 at 1000 Oe (with χ being the magnetic susceptibility equal to M/H). The red solid line is the best fit of the experimental data using the S = 1/2 dinuclear Heisenberg model described in the text. The inset show the Cu(II) complex with Cu-O-Cu bond angles.

elements.content: The experimental data are shown in Figure as a χT vs T plot. At room temperature, the χT product for 2 is 0.99 cm3·K·mol−1 that is higher than the theoretical value of 0.75 cm3·K·mol−1 expected for two noninteracting S = 1/2 CuII ions with g = 2 (C = 0.375 cm3·K·mol−1 each. It is worth mentioning that the CuISCN chains in 2 have no contribution to the overall magnetism of the sample since CuI is a d10 species and diamagnetic). This result suggests a possible g factor higher than 2 and/or the presence of ferromagnetic interactions in this system. This last assumption is confirmed by the temperature dependence of the χT product that increases to a maximum value of 1.19 cm3·K·mol−1 measured at ∼9.5 K. Upon further cooling below 8 K, χT decreases to 1.10 cm3·K·mol−1 at 1.8 K. As already mentioned, the increase of the χT product between 300−8.5 K is clearly indicative of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between the two CuII metal ions, whereas the data below 8 K suggest weak antiferromagnetic interactions between [Cu2] complexes.

elements.content: In these [Cu2] complexes, there are two direct exchange pathways between the CuII sites in 2. The two equatorial planes of the Cu(II) metal ions are connected by a central phenolate bridge that makes an angle of 114.1° between these two planes. The second bridge involves long axial bonds and is not likely to be an effective magnetic exchange pathway, but this second bridge stabilizes the angular arrangement of the two equatorial planes that favors a ferromagnetic interaction. The complex 2 can magnetically be viewed as an S = 1/2 dimer that can be described using an isotropic Heisenberg spin-Hamiltonian (eq ): Ĥ = − 2 J ( Ŝ C u 1 · Ŝ C u 2 ) where J is the CuII−CuII exchange interaction and S i is the spin operator for each CuII. The theoretical expression of the magnetic susceptibility can be established in the low field approximation applying by the van Vleck equation and is given in eq . χ 0 = g 2 N μ B 2 k B T ( 2 e − 2 J / k B T 1 + 3 e − 2 J / k B T ) In order to fit the low temperature χT product (below 8 K), intermolecular (interdimer) interactions must be introduced in the frame of the mean field theory. The following definition of the susceptibility has been used: χ = χ 0 1 − 2 z J′ N g 2 μ B 2 χ 0 where χ0 is the susceptibility of an isolated copper(II) dimer as defined by eq , z is the number of nearest neighbors, and J′ is the intermolecular magnetic interaction between copper(II) dimer units. A least-squares fit of the experimental data was performed and leads to an excellent theory/experience agreement with the following set of parameters: J/k B = +13.0(5) K (or J = +9.0 cm−1) zJ′/k B = −0.30(3) K, (or zJ′ = −0.21 cm−1), and g = 2.25(1) (red solid line in Figures and S10). The magnitude of the intradimer interaction is in close agreement with the values observed for various analogous complexes featuring the same kind of dinucleating ligand and various other exogenous ligands, such as AcO−, HO−, or MeO− where moderately strong ferromagnetic coupling between the S = 1/2 Cu(II) spins was found. The sign of J is consistent with ferromagnetic coupling whereas in the case of complex 1·1.5H2O the magnetic interaction between the Cu(II) ions is weakly antiferromagnetic (J = −0.77 cm−1). Therefore complex 2 possesses an S T = 1 spin ground state in good agreement with the M vs H data below 8 K (). The magnetization saturates above 6 T to near 2.24 μB (at 7 T), in agreement with the presence of two CuII metal ions (S Cu = 1/2) ferromagnetically coupled (S T = 1) in the ground state with a g factor close to 2.24. The M versus H·T −1 data at 1.8, 3, 5, and 8 K () has been fitted remarkably well to an S = 1 Brillouin function confirming a g factor of 2.24(1) in very good agreement to the value deduced from the χT vs T data.

elements.content: In summary, we have shown the NCS− coordination induced reduction and partial extrusion of copper ions as Cu(NCS)2 − from the aqua-bridged [Cu2] complex of a N4O3 ligand leading to the self-replication of in situ generated Cu(NCS)2 − anions in a nonhydrothermal reaction condition at room temperature. This leads to the formation of CuINCS based new 1D anionic parallel chains as new railroad track-like coordination hosts running along the crystallographic b axis. The presence of [Cu2] complexes serve as macrocationic templates which causes condensation of Cu(NCS)2 − units into linear anionic chain framework host. This approach for the synthesis of CuINCS based 1D anionic parallel chain trapped aqua and imidazolidinyl phenolate bridged cationic [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)·H2O]2 units is novel from the perspective of the use of macrocations in the design and synthesis of anionic chain networks. The extruded Cu+ ions are doubly linked by two NCS− ions in antiparallel fashion. These CuINCS based linear chains fence-in the original [Cu2] cations without showing any aqua bridge cleavage and substitution reaction. The results indicate that 1·1.5H2O macrocations play a crucial role as template in the process of constructing 2. Moreover, the structure of the polyanionic chains has great influences on the ultimate layering of the cationic [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)·H2O]2 units which are structurally different from the starting macrocations. Currently, we are engaged in synthesizing analogues complexes of other 3d metal ions showing pseudohalide coordination mediated generation of 1D and 2D coordination framework hosts.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have shown the NCS- coordination induced reduction and partial extrusion of copper ions as Cu(NCS)2 - from the aqua-bridged [Cu2] complex of a N4O3 ligand leading to the self-replication of in situ generated Cu(NCS)2 - anions in a nonhydrothermal reaction condition at room temperature. This leads to the formation of CuINCS based new 1D anionic parallel chains as new railroad track-like coordination hosts running along the crystallographic b axis. The presence of [Cu2] complexes serve as macrocationic templates which causes condensation of Cu(NCS)2 - units into linear anionic chain framework host. This approach for the synthesis of CuINCS based 1D anionic parallel chain trapped aqua and imidazolidinyl phenolate bridged cationic [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)⋅H2O]2 units is novel from the perspective of the use of macrocations in the design and synthesis of anionic chain networks. The extruded Cu+ ions are doubly linked by two NCS- ions in antiparallel fashion. These CuINCS based linear chains fence-in the original [Cu2] cations without showing any aqua bridge cleavage and substitution reaction. The results indicate that 1⋅1.5H2O macrocations play a crucial role as template in the process of constructing 2. Moreover, the structure of the polyanionic chains has great influences on the ultimate layering of the cationic [CuII 2(μ-L)(μ-H2O)⋅H2O]2 units which are structurally different from the starting macrocations. Currently, we are engaged in synthesizing analogues complexes of other 3d metal ions showing pseudohalide coordination mediated generation of 1D and 2D coordination framework hosts.

cln_elements.content:
To the ligand solution (0.50 g, 1.09 mmol) in 15 mL of dichloromethane, methanolic solution of triethylamine (0.55 mL, 4 mmol) was added dropwise to have a solution of pH 7−8. Then methanolic solution of Cu(ClO4)2 ·6H2O (0.80 g, 2.18 mmol) was added slowly with stirring at room temperature for 10 min. The reaction mixture was then stirred for 2 h and the solvent was removed in air. The deep green precipitate obtained was filtered through a glass frit and washed with water followed by methanol and hexane and finally dried in a vacuum over P4O10. Yield: 0.60 g (75%). Anal. Calc. for C27H32N4O9.5Cu2Cl: C, 44.60; H, 4.44; N, 7.70; Cu, 17.47%. Found: C, 44.32; H, 4.37; N, 7.47; Cu, 17.38%. FT-IR spectrum (cm−1, KBr disk): ν = 3388(b), 2936(m), 1627(s), 1595(s), 1537(s), 1447(s), 1312(s), 1094(s), 914(s), 722(s). Molar conductance, ΛM (MeCN solution) 130 Ω−1 cm2 mol−1. UV−vis spectra [λmax, nm (ε, L mol−1 cm−1), DMF solution] 640 (290), 380 (10365), 273 (22040). μeff (tot) = 2.43 μB ; μeff/Cu = 1.71 μB at 298 K.

{[Cu<sup>II</sup> <sub>2</sub>(μ-L)(μ-H<sub>2</sub>O)·H<sub>2</sub>O][Cu<sup>I</sup>(μ<sub> <italic toggle="yes">1,3</italic> </sub>-NCS)<sub>2</sub>]}<italic toggle="yes"> <sub>n</sub> </italic> (<bold>2</bold>)

A methanolic solution of NH4NCS (0.063 g, 79.5 mmol) was added to 1·1.5H2O (0.50 g, 79.5 mmol) in 15 mL of acetonitrile with stirring at room temperature. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1 h and then put aside for evaporation in air. The product obtained was washed thoroughly with water, acetonitrile, and hexane. The bluish green crystals of 2 were obtained from a 1:1 v/v MeCN-DCM mixture after 4 days. Yield: 380 mg (60%). Anal. Calc. for C32H32N8O4Cu3S3: C, 43.59; H, 3.91; N, 10.51; Cu, 23.87%. Found: C, 43.38; H, 3.72; N, 10.31; Cu, 23.76%. FT-IR spectrum (cm−1, KBr disk): ν = 3422(b), 2926(w), 2371(w), 2060(vs), 1636(vs), 1450(m), 1312(m), 1123(m), 768(s), 470(w). cln_elements.content:
The electronic spectrum of 2 in MeCN solution () shows several intense absorption bands in the visible region that are assigned to the allowed d-d and charge transfer transitions. It exhibits a broad band at 621 nm (408 L mol−1 cm−1) due to d-d transition. The higher intensity charge transfer transitions are obtained at 370 and 265 nm, with molar extinction coefficients of 790 and 1990 L mol−1 cm−1, respectively, attributed to PhO− → Cu(II), σ(amino) → Cu(II) LMCT and intraligand charge-transfer transitions.

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out for polycrystalline samples of compound 2 in the temperature range 30−700 °C under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1 (). The first weight loss 4.62% in the range of 30−125 °C corresponds to two water molecules (calcd. 4.5%), and a gradual loss of weight of 39.80% in the next step between 125 and 385 °C corresponds to the loss of three salicylidine moieties (calcd. 39.45%) of the L3−. A third weight loss of 11.67% between 385 and 700 °C may be ascribed to the release of CuS (calcd. 11.97%) with a left over residue of 43.92% for CuNCS (calcd. 45.65%). The other two complexes 1·1.5H2O and 3·H2O show stepwise weight losses in a similar fashion in the temperature ranges of 98−104, 130−235, 233−240, 380−405, and 410−420 °C, respectively ().

The experimental data are shown in Figure as a χT vs T plot. At room temperature, the χT product for 2 is 0.99 cm3·K·mol−1 that is higher than the theoretical value of 0.75 cm3·K·mol−1 expected for two noninteracting S = 1/2 CuII ions with g = 2 (C = 0.375 cm3·K·mol−1 each. It is worth mentioning that the CuISCN chains in 2 have no contribution to the overall magnetism of the sample since CuI is a d10 species and diamagnetic). This result suggests a possible g factor higher than 2 and/or the presence of ferromagnetic interactions in this system. This last assumption is confirmed by the temperature dependence of the χT product that increases to a maximum value of 1.19 cm3·K·mol−1 measured at ∼9.5 K. Upon further cooling below 8 K, χT decreases to 1.10 cm3·K·mol−1 at 1.8 K. As already mentioned, the increase of the χT product between 300−8.5 K is clearly indicative of dominant ferromagnetic interactions between the two CuII metal ions, whereas the data below 8 K suggest weak antiferromagnetic interactions between [Cu2] complexes.
